The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

Since 2005, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA Youth intensive services and is continuing those services for the 2012-13 program year.  Services include outreach, eligibility determination, assessment, job development/placement services, and follow-up services for youth ages 18-21 who are low income with at least one barrier to obtaining employment. Services will be delivered at the work2future Youth Training Center in San Jose and the South County One-Stop in Gilroy.
	 
The City of San Jose's work2future has increased the amount of the agreement by $60,200.00 to add funding for one full-time Employment Specialist and $12,044.00 earned for meeting Performance Based Outcomes for a total amendment value of $72,244.00.

items.item_details:
BACKGROUND: Since 2000, Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide a wide variety of job readiness workshops to Santa Clara County job seekers at multiple locations including the three primary work2future One-Stops (Campbell, Gilroy and San Jose). Additionally, the Workforce Institute has provided online training to equip job seekers with the skills (high level programming, project management, accounting, entrepreneurship, etc.) they need to market themselves in a tight economic market.
 
2011-2012 CONTRACT: On August 9, 2011, the Board of Trustees approved Workforce Institute’s $1,053,300 WIA Workshops Contract awarded by work2future - City of San Jose for FY 2011-2012.
 
FIRST AMENDMENT: On February 14, 2012 the Board of Trustees approved a $580,000 First Amendment to the 2011-2012 WIA Workshops Contract.
 
SECOND AMENDMENT: On June 12, 2012 the Board of Trustees approved a $257,746.00 Second Amendment to the 2011-2012 WIA Workshops Contract.  
 
THIRD AMENDMENT:  This Third Amendment to the 2011-2012 WIA Workshops Contract provides an additional $280,000 for workshops for dislocated Solyndra workers and aligns the line item budget to more accurately reflect the use of online workshops for WIA Adult Dislocated Workers.
	 
The total contract amount for 2011-2012 with all three amendments is $2,171,046.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Third Amendment to the 2011-2012 WIA Workshops Contract.

items.item_details:
Non-resident Tuition Rate:
	 
Education Code Section 76140 requires districts' governing board board to establish the non-resident tuition rate by February 1st for the succeeding year.  Education Code Section 76140(e) enumerates seven options, which are attached, for a district to choose in establishing the rate.
	 
The District's current non-resident tuition rate is $199 per semester unit.  In FY 2011-2012, the District realized $998,985.  In order to retain and attract non-resident students, staff recommends maintaining the rate at $199 per semester unit per Option Four (see attachment).
	 
Capital Outlay Fee:
	 
Education Code 76141 allows for a district to charge a capital outlay fee to any non-resident student.  The amount of the fee shall not exceed the amount that was expended per FTES by the District in FY 2011-2012 for capital outlay, calculated at $48 per semester unit, and shall not exceed 50% of the FY 2011-2012 non-resident tuition rate, calculated at $99.50 per semester unit.
	 
The District's current capital outlay fee is $19 per semester.  In FY 2011-2012, the District realized $14,019.  Staff is recommending increasing the capital outlay fee to $4 per semester unit, which is $48 per semester for a full-time student taking 12 units, to transition from a per semester fee structure to a per semester unit fee structure.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the non-resident tuition rate of $199 per semester unit and the capital outlay fee of $4 per semester unit for Academic Year 2013-2014.

The Chancellor's Initiative - Restructuring/Reorganization 2012-13 will examine and analyze current organizational structures at the unit level using guiding principles which align with the District's future goals and initiatives. 
		 
		 
At the January 8, 2013 Board Meeting, the purpose statement, the guiding principles, the process, the timeline and an outline of the report to be prepared by Fall 2013 was presented as information to the Trustees for review and comment.
		 
At the January 22, 2013 Board Meeting,  The Chancellor is recommending that the following revised guiding principles be adopted by the Board. The revisions are based on comments by the Trustees at the January 8, 2012 meeting.
		 
Guiding Principles for Chancellor's Initiative - Restructuring/Reorganization 2012-13
	 
Visioning for the future with clear goals
Designing institutional structures that are student-centered to empower individuals to be master students
Respecting the strength of the heritages and life experiences of students to build more responsive colleges that reflect the cultural, religious, socioeconomic, linguistic and racial/ethnic diversity of those served. 
Organizing to maximize collaboration and integration
Retooling to increase institutional efficacy, effectiveness and efficiency
Integrating flexibility and the ability to be dynamic
Ensuring the outcomes are not based on âdoing more with lessâ
Honoring any and all provisions of the Collective Bargaining Agreements

items.item_details:
On January 8, 2013, the Board of Trustees was provided the final draft of Student Success Board Policy and Definition (Attachment A) for first reading. This item is now brought back to the Board for action. It is the staff’s recommendation that the Board approve this final draft.
 
Nationwide, the accountability movement has produced a number of definitions and measurements for student success. Invariably, these definitions and metrics focus on completion of degrees, certificates, and transfers. While these are legitimate measures, these do not adequately quantify or evaluate the transformational educational interventions provided by community colleges for community college students. What is needed is a more comprehensive definition of student success that refocuses the issue of student success as a process and not merely an outcome.
	 
In the past few years, San Jose/Evergreen Community College District trustees and chancellor have participated in various efforts for defining and establishing policies for student success at national, state, and local levels through ACCT (Association of Community College Trustees,) CLASS (California Leadership Alliance for Student Success,) the State Legislature on SB-1456 and Student Success Task Force Recommendations, and the District’s participatory governance process including students, faculty and staff.  
	 
At the December 13, 2011, Board of Trustee meeting, the Board acted to adopt a resolution for transmittal to the Board of Governors of the CCC urging them to delay their approval of the Student Success Task Force Recommendations to permit more time for system deliberation. In addition, the Board established a Board Subcommittee on Student Success. The Charge to the Subcommittee was to compare, contrast and analyze various source documents on student success and to present a set of policy constructs that would be consonant with the Board’s “Workplan and Strategic Directions.”  
	 
On February 21, 2012, the Board Subcommittee on Student Success convened an introductory meeting with an expanded constituent group to explore the Committee’s purpose, role and function, guidelines and principles to guide the student success agenda, and definition of terms. Trustee Cruz was established as Chair. The Committee reviewed the CLASS document “Defining a Student Success Agenda.”  Under the leadership of Chancellor Cepeda, the constituent group was charged with a number of tasks.    
	 
The Student Success Constituent Group composed of administrators, faculty, staff, and students (Attachment B) met on six different occasions between March 27 and December 20, 2012. Their work culminated in the development of a definition and proposed board policy on student success including metrics designed to measure policy implementation by the District (Attachment C). 
	 
In addition, it is important to note that task force members scheduled numerous presentations at college forums and at state and national conferences to share the findings and policy directions. All presentations were met with success, including responses from participant evaluations that reaffirmed the significance of the work.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board adopt a Student Success Definition and Policy BP 5050.2

items.item_details:
The José Valdés Math Institute was started in 1989 by José Valdés, an Andrew Hill High School teacher, who developed a math program for underrepresented students to expose them to and assist them in mastering all levels of math through calculus. Twenty-four years later over 20,000 students have been served!
	 
The goal of this presentation is twofold: to thank the administration of the San José/Evergreen Community College District for their support of students enrolled in the Valdés Math Summer Institute, held on the campuses of San José City and Evergreen Valley Colleges, and to present an overview of the extraordinary student success rates after completion of the program. 
	 
Presenter: Julio Pardo, Director
